title: Roshan Mathew
text:
Roshan Mathew (born 22 March 1992) is an Indian actor, who works predominantly in <a href="Malayalam%20cinema">Malayalam films</a>. He had his first major role in the 2016 film "<a href="Puthiya%20Niyamam">Puthiya Niyamam</a>" and his career progressed with his roles in "<a href="Aanandam">Aanandam</a>" (2016) and "<a href="Koode">Koode</a>" (2018). For the lattermost, he won a <a href="SIIMA%20Award">SIIMA Award</a>. He grew further worldwide recognition in "<a href="Moothon">Moothon</a>" (2019), <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a>'s "<a href="Kappela">Kappela</a>" (2020) and <a href="Amazon%20Prime%20Video">Amazon Prime</a>'s "<a href="C%20U%20Soon">C U Soon</a>" (2021). 
Mathew has also appeared in numerous theatre productions based in Chennai and Mumbai. These include "The Glass Menagerie" directed by <a href="Rajit%20Kapur">Rajit Kapoor</a> and "07/07/07" directed by <a href="Faezeh%20Jalali">Faezeh Jalali</a>.
Early life.
Roshan hails from <a href="Changanassery">Changanassery</a>, <a href="Kottayam">Kottayam</a> in the Indian state of <a href="Kerala">Kerala</a>. His father Mathew Joseph is a bank manager in <a href="Canara%20Bank">Canara Bank</a> and his mother Regina Augustine is a retired <a href="Kerala%20Public%20Works%20Department">PWD</a> engineer. He studied in <a href="Kendriya%20Vidyalaya%2C%20Kottayam">Kendriya Vidyalaya, Kottayam</a>. After enrolling in School of Engineering, CUSAT in <a href="Kochi">Kochi</a> he dropped out after one year to study <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Science">B.Sc</a> Physics in <a href="Madras%20Christian%20College">Madras Christian College</a> in <a href="Chennai">Chennai</a>. During his second year in college he developed an interest in acting, and after graduation joined the <a href="https%3A//dramaschoolmumbai.in/">Drama School Mumbai</a>.
Career.
Theatre.
Roshan had been active on stage since school, but his first opportunity to work in professional theatre came when the Chennai-based theatre company "Stagefright Productions" came to Madras Christian College to audition actors for their production of "Dirty Dancing" in August 2010. Roshan bagged the role of "Neal Kellerman", and the production went on stage at The Museum Theatre, Chennai in February 2011. He almost instantly fell in love with theatre, and went on to work with all the prominent Chennai based companies in plays such as "Kamala, Leap, The Uprising, Tughlaq," and "Murder Me Always". He was also part of "The Little Theatre"’s Christmas Pantomime in 2013. 
In Madras Christian College, Roshan along with his friends started a theatre group called "Theatre No. 59" which staged many plays in different colleges in the state. Their production of Alfred Hitchcock/Patrick Hamilton’s "Rope" was widely appreciated, and their revival of Jean Paul Sartre’s "No Exit" won Roshan the award for Best Director at a national level student theatre festival in 2013. 
After moving to Bombay in 2014, Roshan was part of The Drama School Mumbai’s adaptation of <a href="Evgeny%20Schwartz">Eugene Shwartz</a>'s "The Dragon" in 2016. After school, he went to join <a href="Faezeh%20Jalali">Faezeh Jalali</a>'s widely acclaimed production "07/07/07". He then appeared in "Given" directed by Padma Damodaran and written by Shivam Sharma, and <a href="Rajit%20Kapur">Rajit Kapoor</a>'s adaptation of "<a href="The%20Glass%20Menagerie">The Glass Menagerie</a>". He has also directed an original play in Kochi called "A Very Normal Family" with a new team of artists based in the city.
Film.
He made his screen acting debut in a webseries "Tanlines". He made his film debut in 2016 in "<a href="Puthiya%20Niyamam">Puthiya Niyamam</a>" directed by <a href="A.%20K.%20Sajan">A. K. Sajan</a>, followed by a small role in "<a href="Adi%20Kapyare%20Kootamani">Adi Kapyare Kootamani</a>". It was Ganesh Raj's <a href="Aanandam">Aanandam</a> (2016) that put Roshan on the map. The coming of age movie opened to packed houses, and was one of the biggest successes of the year in Malayalam. In 2018, he essayed a role in "<a href="Koode">Koode</a>" directed by <a href="Anjali%20Menon">Anjali Menon</a>. His other notable performances came in "Thottappan" (2019) alongside <a href="Vinayakan">Vinayakan</a>, in "<a href="Viswasapoorvam%20Mansoor">Viswasapoorvam Mansoor</a>" (2017), and "<a href="Orayiram%20Kinakkalal">Orayiram Kinakkalal</a>" (2018). In 2019, he shot to fame by playing Ameer opposite <a href="Nivin%20Pauly">Nivin Pauly</a> in <a href="Geetu%20Mohandas">Geetu Mohandas</a>'s film "<a href="Moothon">Moothon</a>". His upcoming films are "Varthamanam", directed by <a href="Sidhartha%20Siva">Sidhartha Siva</a> along with <a href="Parvathy%20Thiruvothu">Parvathy</a>, his debut tamil film "Cobra" directed by R Ajay Gnanamuthu alongside <a href="Vikram%20%28actor%29">Vikram (actor)</a>. His recently released film is Netflix's Choked directed by <a href="Anurag%20Kashyap">Anurag Kashyap</a> alongside <a href="Saiyami%20Kher">Saiyami Kher</a>, <a href="Kappela">Kappela</a> where he played the lead role alongside <a href="Anna%20Ben">Anna ben</a>and <a href="Sreenath%20Bhasi">Sreenath Bhansi</a> which gained positive reviews and also <a href="C%20U%20Soon">C U Soon</a> alongside <a href="Fahadh%20Faasil">Fahadh Faasil</a>. His performance in the latest <a href="malayalam">malayalam</a> movie <a href="Kuruthi">Kuruthi</a> alongside <a href="Prithviraj%20Sukumaran">Prithviraj Sukumaran</a> also garnered much attention.
